Posts.Content: Albertan wrote: This just started a few days ago, but it runs constantly now.  Not sure if it's due to my chemo - I've had 3 rounds of chemo - or the Herceptin - just had one Herceptin so far, 2 weeks ago.  Not the worst side effect, I know, but my poor nose is going to be rubbed raw!  Any suggestions for what I do about that? Dx 8/2012, IDC, 1cm, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Runny, drippy nose Albertan Aine1981

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 06:49PM Albertan wrote: Kleenex with aloe - I like that idea.  Went out and bought petroleum jelly today - was just thinking how additionally cute I'd look, in addition to having a bald head - to have petroleum jelly smeared on my nose.  Ah, the joys!
Posts.Title: Runny, drippy nose Albertan Aine1981

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2012 11:14AM Albertan wrote: Hi Cindy, Well I am sure no expert, but I got on to this forum again today due to my cancer and treatment.  Interestingly, our cancers and diagnosis look very similar.  When I got my results, I resisted followup treatment from my mastectomy because my lymph nodes were clear and my margins were clear.  However, I too was HER2+ (3+) and that's what convinced me to go the chemo/herceptin route.  See Beesie's answer early in this thread.  It's those rotten rogue cells that could be cruising around.  It was explained to me that IF one of those cells attached to something else (brain, lung, spine, etc) then my cancer would have metasticized and I'd be into palliative chemo.  It took many conversations for me to understand that - I just hadn't understood that.  I guess HER2+ can be aggressive.  So I started chemo last Tuesday and can tell you, it's no picnic.  But I'm only 60 and didn't want to have this stupid thing that we have (HER2+) do any more damage to me.  Good luck. Susan
Posts.Title: Is Chemotherapy necessary? cindyski itsjustme10

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2018 02:30PM Albertan wrote: I came onto this site just to see what others were saying - always good to know we are not alone!! My single mastectomy was about 5 1/2 years ago and I am still bummed. It was my choice not to have reconstruction - totally my choice because I didn't want to undergo more surgery. But I'm a C cup, so I'm pretty lopsided, and there are few prosthetics that will work - the really expensive ones hit a rib or breastbone or something and end up irritating a ligament so much I can't wear them long. So I end up with a very lightweight prosthetic and then end up lopsided too because it tends to ride up. Charming. To hide this, I wear patterned tops almost all the time, because then this lopsidedness isn't so noticeable. The biggest issue? I feel SO unsexy. So unsexy. I can't stand even looking at myself in the mirror after I shower. Still. 5 1/2 years later. However, after reading this forum, I realize I need counselling. I thought all this would go away. But when I hear things like "every body is beautiful and so is yours", it just seem so glib. And sorry, but I don't believe/see it. And I am in good health now, so I've got to appreciate that. Thanks for letting me vent.
Posts.Title: How have you adjusted to being Half Flat? sm627 MexicoHeather

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 03:23PM Albertan wrote: Hi, Was just reading this thread - I am also from Calgary, and I notice that Bennymuffins and websister are also there.  Maybe we can compare stories?  I am also seeing a naturopath and acupuncturist to help get me through this better - I hope! I just had my first chemo last Tuesday - ended up with such bad diarrhea that I ended up in Emerg on Sat night for 6 hours getting 2 litres of fluids pumped into me for dehydration.  When I checked in with triage this morning they said it looked like they needed to reduce my dosage - but at least it showed the chemo was working!!  Guess that's a better way to look at it.  Plan is to get 4 chemo and then Herceptin for a year due to HER2+ status.  Keep wondering what I'm supposed to learn from all this - but just chatted with a friend who said that that learning comes with time.  Take care, all.  Susan
